[[File:Cruz Roja Mexicana - Ambulancia.jpg|thumb|300px|View of a Mexican Red Cross ambulance]] The '''Mexican Red Cross''' is a non-governmental humanitarian assistance organization affiliated with the [[International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies]] to help those in dangerous situations, such as natural disasters, as well as providing human health services. The organization finances its aid, assistance, and education programs through the work of thousands of volunteers and donation from individuals, institutions, organizations, associations and companies.<ref name =gobierno>{{cite web |url=http://www.planetaj.cruzrojamexicana.org.mx/pagnacional/secciones/Juventud/Contenido/PlanetaJ/brinda_tu_auxilio.htm |title=¿Es Cruz Roja del gobierno?|first=Planeta Juventud Cruz Roja Mexicana |accessdate=24 April 2013 |language=Spanish |trans-title=Is the Red Cross part of the government?}}</ref> It originated with a presidential decree in 1910 and was recognized internationally in 1912. Today it participates in national and international aid and disaster relief missions as well as various health services, training in first aid and for emergency medical technicians. Early in its history, it developed a program in nursing, which eventually became the Escuela Nacional de Enfermería y Obstetricia (National School of Nursing and Obstectrics), today part of the [[National Autonomous University of Mexico]].
==History== The organization's history began in 1898, when the [[Spanish Red Cross]] inquired to the government of Mexico about the creation of public institutions to cooperate with military medical units. In 1907, President [[Porfirio Díaz]] signed a decree to have Mexico adhere to the [[First Geneva Convention|Geneva Convention of 1864]], especially to improve the care of the wounded and sick on battlefields. Two years later, the first provisional board of the Mexican Red Cross was established, which assisted in the floods in the city of [[Monterrey]] in 1909. The country's first brigade carrying Red Cross insignia left Mexico City for the stricken Monterrey and their efforts were recognized by the Mexican federal government.<ref name =oficial>{{cite web |url= http://www.cruzrojamexicana.org.mx/?page_id=24|title=Historia|first=Cruz Roja Mexicana |accessdate=24 April 2013 |language=Spanish |trans-title=History }}</ref>
The success of this first effort led to a 1910 presidential decree that provided official recognition to the Mexican Red Cross, allowing for the first official board to be created that same year. In 1912, the organization received international recognition through the [[International Committee of the Red Cross]] (ICRC). The first national convention was held in 1940 and in 1950, the Mexican Red Cross and the [[Secretariat of National Defense (Mexico)|Ministry of Defense]] signed an agreement establishing their relations during peacetime. In 1968, Mexican Red Cross's main hospital opened in the [[Polanco, Mexico City|Polanco neighborhood of Mexico City]].<ref name =ILCE>{{cite web |url=http://redescolar.ilce.edu.mx/redescolar/efemerides/febrero/conme21.htm|title=Fundación de la Cruz Roja Mexicana |first=ILCE |date=14 April 2005 |accessdate=24 April 2013 |language=Spanish |trans-title=Foundation of the Mexican Red Cross }}</ref>
==Uniform, logo and activities== Members and volunteers with the Mexican Red Cross are authorized to wear Red Cross insignia. The Mexican version is nine cm by seven cm badge with a white background. It has a red cross consisting of five equal squares. Underneath the words "Cruz Roja Mexicana" appear in [[Arial]] bold black. Indications of specific sectors and programs appear on the outer edge and a lower band with specific sizes. Identification cards have a color coding system which indicate the types of services the affiliate provides. White is for those in administration, red for volunteers, light blue for medical services, dark blue for other care services, dark green for training and orange for other types of services.<ref name=uniform>{{cite web |url=http://www.cruzrojamexicanasonora.org.mx/descargas/reglamento-nacional-uniformes.pdf |title=Reglamento Nacional de Uniformes e insignias |first=Cruz Roja Mexicana |date=30 October 2005 |accessdate=24 April 2013 |language=Spanish |trans-title=National Regulation Uniforms and logos |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303221011/http://www.cruzrojamexicanasonora.org.mx/descargas/reglamento-nacional-uniformes.pdf |archivedate=3 March 2016 |df= }}</ref>
==Activities of the Mexican Red Cross== The activities of the Mexican Red Cross can be divided into three different sections: volunteer and other worker processing, integration/participation, and assistance/development. The first is designed to generate and update the volunteer databases, integrate the records of the database, provide information regarding the registration process, and credential and update current partners. The integration and participation section consists of plans, projects, general activities of the National Society, specific operational and administrative activities of the areas, committees, commissions, internal or external activities exclusive to volunteer area, and programs derived from the requests of collaboration with similar organizations through institutional agreements. The last section is in charge of the volunteering management instruction, monitoring of the institutional awards system, and following the provisions of the National Ethics Committee relating to sanctions.<ref name=actividades>{{cite web |url=http://www.cruzrojamexicana.org.mx/?page_id=104 |title=Actividades de los programas |publisher=Mexican Red Cross |location=Mexico |accessdate= May 10, 2013 |language=Spanish |trans-title=Program activities}}</ref>
The Mexican Red Cross annually offers training for emergency medical technicians. Course requirements include being over age 18, in good health and fitness, high school diploma, attitude of service, discipling and passing the physical, psychological and skills exams.<ref name =planet-a>{{cite web |url=http://www.planetaj.cruzrojamexicana.org.mx/pagnacional/secciones/Juventud/Contenido/PlanetaJ/Somos/STCR_PresentacionPermanente.pdf|title= Somos todos cruz roja|first=Planeta Juventud Cruz Roja Mexicana |accessdate=24 April 2013 |language=Spanish |trans-title=We all are red cross }}</ref>
== History of the School of Nursing == Training in medical specialties began with the organization as early as 1910, with short courses in first aid. Soon after, they began offering nursing courses as well at two hospitals in Mexico City. In 1925, these courses were adapted to the requirements of the Secretariat of Public Education to organize the Escuela Clínica de Enfermeras de la Cruz Roja Mexicana (Clinic School of Nurses of the Mexican Red Cross).The first graduate was C. Bertha Herver Ritler, which went on to receive a scholarship to go to London and take an instructors course. In 1936, this school is integrated into the [[National Autonomous University of Mexico]], making it the first of its kind in Mexico at the university level. It remained an integral part of the university until 1998, when the university established the [[Escuela Nacional de Enfermería y Obstetrica]] (National School of Nursing and Obstetrics) with is semi autonomous from the main university system.<ref name=enfermería>{{cite web |url=http://www.cruzrojadf.org.mx/escuela-de-enfermeria/ |title=Antecedentes históricos de la Escuela de Enfermería |first=Cruz Roja Mexicana |accessdate=24 April 2013 |language=Spanish |trans-title=History of the School of Nursing |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130111065439/http://www.cruzrojadf.org.mx/escuela-de-enfermeria/ |archivedate=11 January 2013 |df= }}</ref>
==International and national aid missions== Over the years the Mexican Red Cross has participated in a number of high-profile efforts related to disasters and public health. One of the first was the participation of the Red Cross hospital to treat victims of the [[Tlatelolco massacre|1968 student uprising]]. In the 1980s, the organization provided organized relief for the waves of refugees from [[Guatemala]] in [[Chiapas]] and other parts of the south of Mexico. It has also participated in relief efforts after various hurricanes hit Mexico in various places.<ref name =oficial/>
One major event for the organization was the aftermath of the [[1985 Mexico City earthquake]]. Shortly after the event, rescue brigades appeared but the scale of the damage and death was more than they could handle. Not only were there too few, many were under-equipped lacking spikes, sledgehammers, machinery and special equipment. There were also shortages of medicines and blood for medical facilities. Four days after the disaster, on September 23, patients confined to bed, from the Red Cross Polanco, were rearranged in rooms that were decorated with flowers, stuffed animals and even television in order to distract them from the tragic incident.<ref name =cires>{{cite web |url=,http://www.cires.org.mx/1985_es.php|title= EL SISMO DEL 19 DE SEPTIEMBRE DE 1985|accessdate=24 April 2013 |language=Spanish |trans-title=THE EARTHQUAKE OF 19 SEPTEMBER 1985}}</ref>
One recent effort is the collaboration of the Mexican Red Cross with the [[National Crusade Against Hunger (Mexico)|National Crusade Against Hunger]], sponsored by the Mexican federal government. Red Cross participation includes educational programs and the raising of resources. Educational programs include those for mothers caring for infants and those for hospital patients. This also includes workshops on [[Urban agriculture|urban gardens]] and those to teach children about healthy eating habits. The Red Cross mans collection centers for money and supplies and works to distribute these resources in 120 municipalities.<ref name = "diario visión">{{cite web |url=http://www.eldiariovision.com.mx/noticia/nota,19662/#.UXbEsJVydwc|title= Colaborará la Cruz Roja Mexicana en la Cruzada Nacional Contra el Hambre |first= Diario Visión de Michoacán |date=12 April 2013 |accessdate=24 April 2013 |language=Spanish |trans-title=Mexican Red Cross support the National Crusade Against Hunger }}</ref>
Apart from solely providing aid to people in their nation, the Mexican Red Cross has helped victims of natural or social disasters in other countries. One of these is their participation in relief efforts after [[Hurricane Katrina disaster relief|Hurricane Katrina]], sending food and other supplies.<ref name =lacronica>{{cite web |url=http://www.cronica.com.mx/notas/2005/201071.html|title= Empacan ayuda para damnificados de EU en la Cruz Roja Mexicana |first=La crónica |date=7 September 2005 |accessdate=24 April 2013 |language=Spanish |trans-title=Packed U.S. Disaster Relief in the Mexican Red Cross }}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}

[[File:Kerk Wechelderzande.png|thumb|Modern-day view of [[Wechelderzande]] where the murder occurred ]] The '''murder of Karel Van Noppen''' was a high-profile assassination of a government livestock inspector in [[Belgium]] in 1995. Van Noppen had been investigating illegal practices by farmers and businessmen in Belgium and was shot dead by assailants outside his house in the village of [[Wechelderzande]] in the [[Antwerp (province)|Province of Antwerp]]. A number of people connected with the illegal supply of [[growth hormones]] to livestock were sentenced in connection with the murder.
=="Hormone Mafia"== The use of [[growth hormones]] on livestock has the potential to increase the profit per animal between ten and 100 percent. However, the use of such hormones has been banned by the [[European Union]] since 1989 and so organised crime, motivated by the immense profits, moved into the business. This was a particular concern in Belgium, where several government inspectors had been threatened or had attempts made on their lives.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/why-the-mafia-is-into-your-beef-1342852.html|title=The Independent - Why the mafia is into your beef|work=The Independent|accessdate=8 October 2014}}</ref>
==Murder== In February 1995, 43-year-old Karel Van Noppen, who had been investigating the phenomenon, was shot dead outside his front door. The killing provoked outrage throughout Belgium, with a torchlight procession led by his widow in Flanders and calls to investigate and better regulate the cattle industry.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/belgians-march-in-memory-of-hormone-mafia-victim-1319918.html|title=The Independent - Belgians march in memory of 'hormone mafia' victim|work=The Independent|accessdate=8 October 2014}}</ref> In 2002, a court sentenced Albert Barrez, Carl de Schutter and Germain Daenen to 25 years each for their roles in the murder, while another man, Alex Vercauteren received a life sentence without parole.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/2027719.stm|title=BBC News - Belgian hormone killers jailed|publisher=|accessdate=8 October 2014}}</ref>
==In popular culture== The 2011 Belgian crime drama ''[[Bullhead (film)|Bullhead]]'', directed by [[Michaël R. Roskam]], is loosely based on the incident and the hormone mafia.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-17041056|title=BBC News - Bullhead: Oscar contender rooted in real Belgian murder|work=BBC News|accessdate=8 October 2014}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

{{EngvarB|date=January 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2017}} {{Infobox military conflict |conflict=Nukapu Expedition |partof= | image= Nukapu Rev. A. Penny.jpg | image_size = 300 |caption=''Nukapu, circa 1870.'' |date=October 1871 - February 1872 |place=[[Nukapu]], [[Solomon Islands]], [[Pacific Ocean]] |result= British victory |combatant1={{flag|United Kingdom}} |combatant2={{flagicon|Solomon Islands}} [[Nukapu]] |commander1={{flagicon|United Kingdom|naval}} [[Albert Hastings Markham]] |commander2={{flagicon|Solomon Islands|naval}} unknown |strength1= |strength2= |casualties1=1 killed
2 wounded
1 sloop-of-war damaged |casualties2=20-30 killed
~3 war canoes sunk |notes= }} {{Nukapu Conflict}} The '''Nukapu Expedition''' occurred between October 1871 and February 1872 and was a [[United Kingdom|British]] [[punitive expedition|punitive operation]] in response to the murder of [[Bishop]] [[John Coleridge Patteson]] by the natives of [[Nukapu]]. A [[Royal Navy]] warship was sent to the island and it sank a group of hostile [[canoe|war-canoes]] and landed men to attack a fortified village. ==Expedition== In October 1871, the screw [[sloop-of-war]] [[HMS Rosario (1860)|HMS ''Rosario'']] was operating against [[South Sea Islands|South Seas]] [[blackbirder]]s when her captain, [[Commander|Acting-Commander]] [[Albert Hastings Markham]] received orders to sail for Nukapu in the [[Solomon Islands]]. A contemporary newspaper described the events thus: {{cquote|''The Rosario{{'}}s boat had got to within 50 yards of the mainland when the natives commenced their war dance and made other hostile indications. They then sent a shower of arrows at the Rosario{{'}}s boat, which however, all fell short. The boat then returned to the ship to report the attack, and to ask permission to return it. The boat was ordered to return, and the ship was cleared for action, and opened fire with shell from the [[RBL 40 pounder Armstrong gun|40-pounder Armstrong]], and the [[RML 7 inch gun|7in. six and a half ton gun]]; while the crew of the boat opened fire with their rifles. The Rosario made a circuit of the island, and when abreast of the native village fired on it with shell at 2,300 yards. At 4 p.m., it being high water, the boats were able to cross the reef, and four of them advanced on the village with small arms, and engaged the natives, who kept up a continual discharge of arrows; the ship sent in shell at a range of a mile. After firing several hundred rounds, the men landed from the boats and drove the natives in from the beach. Here one of the arrows struck Corporal Marcus in the arm, and the wound afterwards proved fatal. The native canoes were destroyed, and the seamen pulled on to the village, where one of them received two bad wounds, but ultimately recovered from their effects. The village proved to be very strongly fortified with stonework, which was thrown up in front of each hut. In a few minutes the native habitations were set in flames. It was estimated that from 20 to 30 natives were killed in the engagement.|20px|20px|The ''Rosario'' and the Murderers of Bishop Patteson, reported in ''The Argus''{{cite news|title=The ''Rosario'' and the Murderers of Bishop Patteson|newspaper=[[The Argus (Australia)|The Argus]]| location = [[Melbourne]] |date= 15 February 1872|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article5859743}}Montgomery, pg. 32-323}} Markham published an account of the cruise under the title ''The cruise of the ''Rosario'' amongst the New Hebrides and Santa Cruz Islands, exposing the recent atrocities connected with the kidnapping of natives in the South Seas.''{{cite book |title=The cruise of the ''Rosario'' amongst the New Hebrides and Santa Cruz Islands |last=Markham |first=Albert Hastings |authorlink=Albert Hastings Markham |year=1873 |publisher=Sampson Low, Marston, Low, and Searle |location=London}} The measures taken by ''Rosario'' became the subject of questions in the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]],{{cite web|url=http://hansard.millbanksystems.com/commons/1872/mar/11/question-5#S3V0209P0_18720311_HOC_34|title=Hansard, 11 March 1872|accessdate=2009-11-19|quote=Mr W Johnston asked the Under Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, If there is any foundation for the statement that Her Majesty's ship ''Rosario'' has shelled and destroyed the village in the Island of Nukapu, in which resided the natives who murdered Bishop Patteson; and, if so, by whose orders this was done?}} and Markham's book on the subject may well have been prompted by them. The book itself makes clear that Markham clearly understood the cycle of violence and deplored both the murderous activities of the Blackbirders, and the apparent need for further violence in restoring order. ==See also== *[[Fiji Expeditions (disambiguation)|Fiji Expeditions]] *[[Sumatran Expeditions (disambiguation)|Sumatran Expeditions]] *[[Formosan Expedition]] ==References== {{reflist}} *{{cite book |last=Montgomery|first=Charles |coauthors=|edition= |title=The Shark God: encounters with ghosts and ancestors in the South Pacific |year=2004|publisher=HarperCollins Publishing |location= |isbn=0-06-076516-X}} {{coord missing|Solomon Islands}} [[Category:History of the Solomon Islands]] [[Category:Naval battles involving the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Battles involving the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Battles involving canoes|Nukapu]] [[Category:Punitive expeditions of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Conflicts in 1871]] [[Category:Conflicts in 1872]] [[Category:Violence against indigenous peoples]]

{{Infobox Civil Conflict | title = Occupy the SEC |partof = the [["Occupy" protests]] | image = File:Occupy the SEC logo.png | caption = | date = October 2011 – ''ongoing'' | place = [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]], [[United States]] | coordinates = | causes = [[Financial regulation|Financial regulatory activity]], [[Big Business#Influence over government|corporate influence over government]], [[economic inequality]], ''inter alia''. | status = Ongoing | goals = | result = | methods = [[Demonstration (people)|Demonstration]], [[activism]], correspondence | notes = {{URL|http://www.occupythesec.org}} }}
'''Occupy the SEC''' (OSEC) is an [[Activism|activist group]] which aims to influence financial regulators to work for the [[public interest]]. The "SEC" in its name refers to the US [[Securities and Exchange Commission]], but OSEC's scope covers all [[Financial regulation|financial regulatory]] activity. OSEC was formed and developed as an outgrowth and working group of [[Occupy Wall Street]].<ref name="Johnson"/>
Among its members are employees or former employees of some of the largest [[Financial institution|financial firm]]s.<ref name="washingtonpost">{{cite news | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/wonkblog/post/occupy-the-regulatory-system/2012/04/27/gIQAjo21lT_blog.html | title=Occupy the regulatory system! | publisher=''[[The Washington Post]]'' | date=April 27, 2012 | accessdate=12 April 2014 | author=Khimm, Suzy}}</ref> They have been described as "a counterweight to the deep-pocket lobbying push" by financial firms against reform.<ref name="washingtonpost" />
== History == OSEC was founded in October 2011 as a working group of [[Occupy Wall Street]],<ref name="Johnson"/> the protest movement which started in Zuccotti Park in Lower Manhattan on September 17, 2011. After initially meeting on a bench in Zuccotti Park, late October 2011,<ref name="washingtonpost" /> the group evolved into a bi-weekly "book club" at a diner near the park,<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.businessweek.com/finance/occupy-the-sec-weighs-in-on-the-volcker-rule-02142012.html | title=Occupy the SEC Weighs In on the Volcker Rule | publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] | date=February 14, 2012 | accessdate=12 April 2014 | author=Weise, Karen}}</ref> and then met weekly in the atrium of 60 Wall Street.<ref name="bloomberg">{{cite web | url=http://www.bloombergview.com/articles/2012-03-01/occupy-the-sec-writes-new-volcker-rule-script-commentary-by-susan-antilla | title=Occupy Vigilantes Write New Volcker Rule Script: Susan Antilla | publisher=Bloomberg | date=February 29, 2012 | accessdate=12 April 2014 | author=Antilla, Susan}}</ref> The group first gained attention after tackling a response to the proposed [[Volcker Rule]], part of the [[Dodd–Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act|Dodd-Frank Act of 2010]], that would severely limit proprietary trading at commercial banks, similar to the [[Glass–Steagall Act|Glass Steagall Act of 1933]]. OSEC drafted answers to questions regarding the proposed rule, which were included in a 325-page comment letter submitted to the SEC on February 13, 2012.<ref name="Salmon"/><ref name="Scribd"/>
== Volcker Rule comment letter and follow-up == Submitted by OSEC to the [[Securities and Exchange Commission|U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission]] on February 13, 2012, the 325-page comment letter<ref name="Scribd"/><ref>{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RytnAgAAQBAJ&pg=PT91 | title=Republic of Outsiders: The Power of Amateurs, Dreamers and Rebels | publisher=The New Press | author=Quart, Alissa | year=2013 | pages=(unlisted) | isbn=1595588949}}</ref> was hailed as "amazing", describing how the authors went through the rule "line by line, explaining where it's useless and where it can and should be improved."<ref name="Salmon"/> Others suggested OSEC was doing "the day-in, day-out grind of policymaking—calling legislators, responding to regulatory agencies, learning the issues..."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/moneybox/2012/02/14/occupy_the_sec_releases_325_page_comment_letter_on_quot_volcker_rule_quot_proposals.html |date=February 14, 2012 |title=Occupy the SEC Releases 325-Page Comment Letter on "Volcker Rule" Proposals |first=Matthew |last=Yglesias |publisher=Slate}}</ref> OSEC's comment letter was close to the lengthiest and most detailed of the 16,000 letters sent to the SEC,<ref name="bloomberg" /> with the vast majority coming from industry insiders. This letter was cited 284 times by the Federal Reserve Board when the regulations were ultimately put into effect in 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/wonkblog/wp/2013/12/11/the-volcker-rule-cites-the-occupy-movement-284-times/ |title=The Volcker rule cites the Occupy Movement 284 times |first=Lydia |last=DePillis |publisher=Washington Post |date=December 11, 2013 | accessdate=25 January 2015}}</ref>
On February 26, 2013, OSEC filed a suit in the Eastern District Court of New York naming the Federal Reserve, the SEC, CFTC, OCC, FDIC, and the U.S. Department of the Treasury calling for implementation of the "[[Volcker Rule]]" (Section 619 of the [[Dodd–Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act|Dodd-Frank Act of 2010)]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://occupythesec.nycga.net/2013/02/27/occupy-the-sec-sues-federal-reserve-sec-cftc-occ-fdic-and-u-s-treasury-over-volcker-rule-delays/ | title=Occupy the SEC Sues Federal Reserve, SEC, CFTC, OCC, FDIC and U.S. Treasury Over Volcker Rule Delays | publisher=Occupy the SEC blog | date=February 27, 2013 | accessdate=12 April 2014 | author=Occupy the SEC}}</ref>
== Ongoing activities == After the Volcker Rule comment letter, the group continued to engage in regulatory matters where it felt that the 99% needed to be represented.
In June 2012, Occupy the SEC submitted a 7-page letter to the [[United States Senate Committee on Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs|Senate Banking Committee]] prior to JP Morgan CEO [[Jamie Dimon]]'s testimony.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/06/12/occupy-the-sec-jamie-dimon_n_1591465.html | title='Occupy The SEC' Has Exactly 11 Questions For Jamie Dimon | publisher=[[Huffington Post]] | date=June 12, 2012 | accessdate=12 April 2014 | first=Jillian | last=Berman}}</ref>
In December 2012, OSEC submitted an [[amicus curiae|amicus brief]] in the case of Gabelli v. SEC, in which the [[Supreme Court of the United States|Supreme Court]] will decide when the statute of limitations clock begins for certain [[fraud]] actions brought by the government – from the time the fraud was last committed or from the time the fraud was discovered.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.americanbar.org/content/dam/aba/publications/supreme_court_preview/briefs-v2/11-1274_resp_amcu_ots.authcheckdam.pdf | title=Brief of Occupy the SEC as ''Amicus Curiae'' in Support of Respondent | publisher=[[American Bar Association]] | accessdate=12 April 2014}}</ref>
On February 15, 2013, OSEC submitted a formal comment letter on money market fund reform to the [[Financial Stability Oversight Council| Financial Stability Oversight Council (FSOC)]]. The letter urged FSOC to move forward with money market reforms, supported the proposals for floating NAVs and buffers to absorb losses but pointed out that broader reforms were required as well.<ref>{{ cite web | url=http://www.regulations.gov/#!documentDetail;D=FSOC-2012-0003-0128 | title=OSEC Comment to FSOC on MMFs | date=15 February 2013 | accessdate=2015-01-25}}</ref> The letter was cited several times by the SEC when they promulgated reforms to market fund regulations.<ref>{{ cite web | url=http://www.regulations.gov/#!documentDetail;D=SEC-2014-1371-0001 | title=SEC MMF Reform Rule | date=14 October 2014 | accessdate=2015-01-25}}</ref>
In July 2013, OSEC submitted an [[amicus curiae|amicus brief]] to the US Supreme Court regarding overly broad interpretations of securities litigation laws.<ref>{{ cite web | url=http://www.americanbar.org/content/dam/aba/publications/supreme_court_preview/briefs-v2/12-79-12-86-12-88_resp_amcu_oc-sec.pdf | title=OSEC Troice Amicus | date=29 July 2013 | accessdate=2015-01-25}}</ref>
In September 2014, OSEC submitted an [[amicus curiae|amicus brief]] to the US Supreme Court in the case of Omnicare v. Laborers Pension Fund supporting the rights to sue securities issuers and their agents for material misrepresentation.<ref>{{ cite web | url=http://www.americanbar.org/content/dam/aba/publications/supreme_court_preview/BriefsV4/13-435_resp_amcu_otsec.pdf | title=OSEC Omnicare v Laborers Amicus | date=28 August 2014 | accessdate=2015-01-25}}</ref>
In March 2015, OSEC filed an amicus brief to the Supreme Court in Bank of America N.A. v. Caulkett, and Bank of America N.A. v. Toledo-Cardona. OSEC also filed comment letters relating to the systemic risks created or propagated by asset managers to the Financial Stability Oversight Council (FSOC) and in May a letter on designation of asset managers as [[SIFI | SIFIs (Systemically Important Financial Institutions)]] to the global [[Financial Stability Board| Financial Stability Board (FSB)]]. <ref>{{cite web|title=OSEC amicus brief in Bank of America v. Caulkett |url=http://www.americanbar.org/content/dam/aba/publications/supreme_court_preview/BriefsV5/13-1421_amicus_resp_occupy.authcheckdam.pdf|accessdate=March 31, 2015}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|title=OSEC comment to FSOC on asset management and systemic risk|url=http://www.regulations.gov/#!documentDetail;D=FSOC-2014-0001-0060|accessdate=March 31, 2015}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|title=OSEC comment to FSB on asset management and systemic risk |url=http://www.financialstabilityboard.org/wp-content/uploads/Occupy-the-SEC-OSEC.pdf| accessdate=June 15, 2015}}</ref>
In November 2015, the group submitted a comment letter to the CFTC on aggregate position limits. They also organized an effort to petition Congress to oppose a bill backed by the Koch brothers. It generated over 1,000 letters. <ref>{{cite web|title=OSEC comment to CFTC on aggregate position limits |url=http://comments.cftc.gov/PublicComments/ViewComment.aspx?id=60558&SearchText=| accessdate=8 January 2016}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|title=Yahoo finance article on HR 4002 |url=https://finance.yahoo.com/news/congress-making-even-harder-crack-111500742.html| publisher=finance.yahoo.com | accessdate=8 January 2016}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|title=Petition to oppose HR 4002 |url=http://www.petition2congress.com/19001/join-occupy-sec-in-urging-congress-to-oppose-hr4002-criminal-code/| accessdate=8 January 2016}}</ref>
== Reception == According to ''The Economist'', Occupy the SEC's "contributions to the debate on [[regulatory reform]] (including a tome on the Volcker Rule) have been well-received even by some leading regulators".<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.economist.com/node/21563341 | title=Occupy Wall Street: Afterthoughts | publisher=''[[The Economist]]'' | date=September 22, 2012 | accessdate=12 April 2014}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2|refs= <ref name="Johnson">{{cite news | url=https://economix.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/01/16/occupy-the-s-e-c-has-its-day/?_php=true&_type=blogs&_r=0 | title=An Occupy Wall Street Offshoot Has Its Day | publisher=''[[The New York Times]]'' | date=January 16, 2014 | accessdate=12 April 2014 | author=Johnson, Simon}}</ref> <ref name="Salmon">{{cite news | url=http://blogs.reuters.com/felix-salmon/2012/02/14/occupys-amazing-volcker-rule-letter/ | title=Occupy's amazing Volcker Rule letter | publisher=[[Reuters]] | date=February 14, 2012 | accessdate=12 April 2014 | author=Salmon, Felix}}</ref> <ref name="Scribd">{{cite web | url=https://www.scribd.com/doc/81484886/Occupy-the-SEC-Comment-Letter-on-the-Volcker-Rule | title=OSEC comment letter re: Volcker Rule | date=13 February 2012 | accessdate=2013-02-11}}</ref> }}
==Further reading== * {{cite web | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/wonkblog/wp/2013/12/11/the-volcker-rule-cites-the-occupy-movement-284-times/ | title=The Volcker rule cites the Occupy Movement 284 times | publisher=''[[The Washington Post]]'' | date=December 11, 2013 | accessdate=25 September 2014 | author=DePillis, Lydia}} * {{cite web | url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/opinion/2013/03/05/occupy-sec-takes-big-banks-their-own-turf/xRmDFTt81dTpuP1CJzio5O/story.html | title=Occupy the SEC takes on big banks on their own turf (opinion) | publisher=''[[Boston Globe]]'' | date=March 5, 2013 | accessdate=12 April 2014 | author=McMorrow, Paul}} * {{cite news | url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/02/14/occupy-sec-volcker-rule_n_1276903.html | title=Occupy The SEC Marches In Support Of A Strong Volcker Rule | publisher=[[Huffington Post]] | date=February 14, 2012 | accessdate=12 April 2014 | author=Eichler, Alexander}}

{{Orphan|date=April 2016}}
'''Post-graduate service''' (or, post-graduate [[volunteering]]) is a range of commitments that people who have recently graduated with a [[college degree]] can make to volunteer in a community in need. Discussed within the setting of colleges and universities, post-graduate service is seen as an alternative to entering the [[workforce]] or going to a graduate or professional school.<ref>[http://www.grinnell.edu/offices/socialcommitment/postgradopps Post-Graduation Service Opportunities - Social Commitment | Grinnell College<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110613040013/http://www.grinnell.edu/offices/socialcommitment/postgradopps |date=2011-06-13 }}</ref>
A post-graduate volunteer works for a [[non-profit organization]] on a full-time and long-term basis. Non-profits can have internal programs for taking on such volunteers.<ref>[http://www.redcloudschool.org/volunteers/volunteers.htm VOLUNTEER PROGRAM :: Red Cloud Indian School<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110215105422/http://www.redcloudschool.org/volunteers/volunteers.htm |date=2011-02-15 }}</ref> But what is more commonly meant by "post-graduate service" is when graduates interested in service of this kind become applicants to broader programs that have relationships with multiple (in the case of [[AmeriCorps]], ''thousands'' of) non-profits.<ref name=autogenerated5>[http://socialconcerns.nd.edu/postgraduate/about_service.shtml About Post-Graduate Service: Center for Social Concerns<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720011922/http://socialconcerns.nd.edu/postgraduate/about_service.shtml |date=2011-07-20 }}</ref> These programs, upon accepting the graduate, "place" him or her with a non-profit.<ref name=autogenerated3>[http://www.villanova.edu/campusministry/events/volunteerfair/ Post Graduate Volunteer Service Fair<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> The placement can resemble paid employment and usually demands a commitment of one (or two) year(s).<ref name=autogenerated2>[http://www.spc.edu/pages/2490.asp Post-Graduate Volunteer Opportunities<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101129235943/http://spc.edu/pages/2490.asp |date=2010-11-29 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.lmu.edu/studentlife/csa/postgraduate.htm Post-graduate Service Opportunities<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110130010326/http://www.lmu.edu/studentlife/csa/postgraduate.htm |date=2011-01-30 }}</ref>
==Terminology==
In wider circles, the terms “service” and “volunteering” tend to be invoked when the person is unpaid. Thus, here they are used somewhat differently, as many who engage in post-graduate service are given [[stipend]]s or are compensated.<ref name=autogenerated1>[http://www.bc.edu/offices/careers/jobs/volunteer/volunteerlistings.html Volunteer Opportunities Listings - Boston College<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110320104754/http://www.bc.edu/offices/careers/jobs/volunteer/volunteerlistings.html |date=2011-03-20 }}</ref> There are programs that care to address this—by referring to their participants as “members” and not “volunteers.”<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cityyear.org/whowelookfor.aspx |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-02-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110222205559/http://www.cityyear.org/whowelookfor.aspx |archivedate=2011-02-22 |df= }}</ref> There are also some programs designed for recently graduated students, such as [[Teach For America]], that have certain similarities to post-graduate service but offer members more than mere compensation but full salaries and thus are not generally considered post-graduate service.<ref>[http://www.teachforamerica.org/the-corps-experience/compensation/ Compensation - Teach For America<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> However, with post-graduate service being an [[umbrella term]] that has meaning insofar as university students and staff members use it and find it helpful, these exclusions and exceptions are not highly significant.
==Variations in post-graduate service==
The organizations that fit this umbrella term—i.e., that take on post-graduate volunteers, either for their own use or to place with separate non-profits—differ in several important ways.<ref name=autogenerated2 /><ref>[http://socialconcerns.nd.edu/postgraduate/pg_opportunities.shtml Post-graduate Opportunities: Center for Social Concerns<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
===Governmental character=== The [[United States federal government]] has launched its own programs aimed at putting volunteers in places within the country or in the world that have been identified as needful of such service. The [[Corporation for National and Community Service]] was established in 1993, and while it takes volunteers of all ages across multiple programs, its AmeriCorps program is an option that many recent college graduates choose.<ref>[http://www.nationalservice.gov/about/role_impact/history.asp NationalService.gov > Our History and Legislation<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Meanwhile, the [[Peace Corps]] has been in existence since 1961, placing volunteers in (among other contexts) third-world poverty, that they might be partner to local communities efforts at self-improvement.<ref>[http://www.peacecorps.gov/index.cfm?shell=about.history History | About Us | Peace Corps<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110122114805/http://www.peacecorps.gov/index.cfm?shell=about.history |date=2011-01-22 }}</ref> With these programs understood to be “governmental post-graduate service”, most of the rest of what is considered post-graduate service is non-governmental.
===Location=== Some organizations put volunteers in domestic service, others in international service (here “domestic” refers to the United States of America).<ref name=autogenerated3 /> In addition to the Peace Corps, examples of international post-graduate service programs would be Jesuit Volunteer Corps International and Good Shepherd Volunteers International. Domestic programs include [[City Year]] and Loretto Volunteers. Parallelistically, non-profit organizations that have their own programs for taking on full-time volunteers ''which are domestic'' include Nazareth Farm and Amate House. Non-profits that have their own programs for taking on full-time volunteers ''which are international'' include Farm of the Child and Working Boys’ Center.
===Religious character=== Organizations can differ in their religious character. Some programs are entirely [[secular]] (or, non-faith-based) and some are faith-based, including being affiliated with [[religion]]s, [[Religious denomination|denominations]], or [[religious institute]]s. Many organizations that would be called post-graduate service programs are in fact the lay missioner/volunteer arm of a particular religious institute or [[society of apostolic life]].<ref>[http://www.mklaymissioners.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=section&id=17&Itemid=24 Maryknoll Lay Missioners - Who We Are<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> This includes some programs already named, as well as the Augustinian Volunteers, [http://www.gsvolunteers.org Good Shepherd Volunteers], Dominican Volunteers, [[Maryknoll Lay Missioners]], Cabrini Mission Corps (Cabrini Sisters), and Little Sisters of the Assumption Family in Mission (Little Sisters of the Assumption).
===Housing=== A post-graduate volunteer’s [[house|housing]] and living situation varies greatly across programs. Some volunteer residences would qualify as [[intentional community]].<ref name=autogenerated5 /> In such cases, volunteers may not be expected to contribute to housing costs, as when the house belongs to or is paid for by the post-graduate service program.<ref name=autogenerated1 /> In other cases, volunteers are expected to procure their own housing.<ref>AmeriCorps VISTA Handbook, Ch. 13, {{cite web |url=http://www.nationalservice.gov/help/vistahandbook/chapter13.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-02-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100714022147/http://www.nationalservice.gov/help/vistahandbook/chapter13.html |archivedate=2010-07-14 |df= }}</ref>
===Programs' values and philosophies=== Some differences lie in program philosophies. Many organizations that place or take volunteers have distinct approaches to service, often integrating their understandings of service with [[values]] or “pillars” that present their vision of how a volunteer (or a person generally) should live.<ref name=autogenerated4>[http://www.canisius.edu/camp_minist/volunteer_service.asp Canisius College - Post Graduate Service Year<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> For instance, the [[Jesuit Volunteer Corps]] identifies its “values” as [[social justice]], [[community]], [[spirituality]], and [[simple living]].<ref>[https://www.jesuitvolunteers.org/default.cfm/PID=1.25.10 Jesuit Volunteers<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> An integrated approach to service means living out these values and includes specific actions for the volunteers that speak to them and build on them.<ref name=autogenerated4 />
==Post-graduate service on college campuses==
Colleges and universities in the United States can occasionally be found to have structures in place, or particular staff members, who—like [[career development]] departments—aid interested students in their search for the right service program.<ref>[http://www.fordham.edu/mission/mission_and_ministry/dorothy_day_center_f/current_students/post_graduate_opport_71218.asp Post-Graduate Volunteer Opportunities<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> The Catholic Volunteer Network (formerly called the Catholic Network of Volunteer Service) is made up of 200 member organizations that take post-graduate volunteers.<ref>[https://www.catholicvolunteernetwork.org/aboutus/index.php Catholic Volunteer Network<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110725145107/https://www.catholicvolunteernetwork.org/aboutus/index.php |date=2011-07-25 }}</ref> Many of these organizations report to CVN the colleges and universities from which their volunteers come, such that CVN can publicize which colleges are sending the most students into volunteering positions within their network. In previous rank orderings, the [[University of Notre Dame]] has topped CVN’s list.<ref>Faith Works (newsletter of the Catholic Network of Volunteer Service), Winter 2007, {{cite web |url=http://www.cnvs.org/docs_PDF/faithworks/fw_2007_Winter.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-02-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110725184407/http://www.cnvs.org/docs_PDF/faithworks/fw_2007_Winter.pdf |archivedate=2011-07-25 |df= }}</ref>
==Post-graduate service and future graduate studies==
Post-graduate service is chosen by a person when she or he has just acquired a degree and, because it is a full-time commitment, thus precludes immediate entrance to a more advanced [[degree program]]. For this reason, many do post-graduate service with an interest in going to graduate school upon their return. To this point, CNVS membership surveys from 2001-2006 reported that a third of all returning full-time volunteers followed their period of service with graduate-level studies <ref>"Post-graduate Service' PowerPoint Presentation" by CNVS task force, {{cite web |url=http://socialconcerns.nd.edu/postgraduate/documents/NDPGSpresentation.ppt |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-02-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720011927/http://socialconcerns.nd.edu/postgraduate/documents/NDPGSpresentation.ppt |archivedate=2011-07-20 |df= }}</ref> This approach acts on the hope that the experience of long-term service—particularly experience in building relationships with the poor (should that be present)—makes one a more visibly mature, independent, and determined applicant.
== References == {{Reflist}}

{{Use mdy dates|date=April 2018}} {{Infobox person |image = |name = Sara Jane Olson |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1947|1|16|mf=y}} |birth_place = [[Fargo, North Dakota]] |caption = |birth_name = Kathleen Ann Soliah |movement = [[Symbionese Liberation Army]] |organization = }} '''Sara Jane Olson''' (born '''Kathleen Ann Soliah''' on January 16, 1947) was a member of the [[Symbionese Liberation Army]] (SLA) in the 1970s. She grew up in [[Palmdale, California]], the daughter of [[Norwegian-American]] parents,<ref name=tribune>{{cite news |title=June 27, 1999: The life and times of Sara Jane Olson |author=Chuck Haga |date=March 21, 2008 |url=http://www.startribune.com/printarticle/?id=16894551 |work=Star Tribune |location=Minneapolis |accessdate=July 29, 2015}}</ref><ref name=seattle>{{cite news| url=http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=20000110&slug=A20000112010329 | work=The Seattle Times | title=A Radical Change? | date=January 10, 2000}}</ref> Elsie Soliah (née Engstrom)<ref name=tribune/> and [[Palmdale High School]] English teacher<ref name=tribune/> and coach Martin Soliah.<ref name=tribune/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/OLSON+STUNS+COURTROOM+SLA+FUGITIVE+PLEADS+GUILTY,+BUT+LATER+SAYS+...-a079647796|title=Olson Stuns Courtroom SLA Fugitive Pleads Guilty, but Later Says She's Not |publisher=thefreelibrary.com|accessdate=July 29, 2015}}</ref> She went into hiding in 1976 after having been indicted in a bombing case. She has lived much of her life in [[Minnesota]] under the alias Sara Jane Olson, which is now her legal name. Arrested in 1999, she pleaded guilty in 2001 to two counts of possessing explosives with intent to murder, and in 2003 to second-degree murder, both stemming from her SLA activities in the 1970s. She received a sentence of 14 years in prison.
She was mistakenly released for five days in March 2008, due to an error made in calculating her parole, before being rearrested.<ref>[http://www.cnn.com/2008/CRIME/03/22/olson.custody/index.html "70's radical-turned-housewife back in prison"], CNN, March 22, 2008</ref> She was finally released on parole on March 17, 2009.<ref>[http://www.baltimoresun.com/news/sns-ap-sla-olson,0,5802667.story "Former 1970s radical freed from Calif. prison, to be paroled home in Minnesota"], ''The Baltimore Sun'', AP, March 17, 2009</ref>
==Symbionese Liberation Army== Kathleen Soliah was born in [[Fargo, North Dakota]], while her family were living in [[Barnesville, Minnesota]].<ref name=tribune/> When she was eight, her conservative [[Lutheran]]<ref name=tribune/> family relocated to Southern California. After graduating from the [[University of California, Santa Barbara]], Soliah moved to [[Berkeley, California]], with her boyfriend, [[James Kilgore]]. There, she met [[Angela Atwood]] at an acting audition where they both won lead roles. They became inseparable during the play's run. Atwood tried to sponsor Soliah into the SLA. Regardless, Soliah and Kilgore, along with her brother Steve and sister Josephine, followed the SLA closely without joining.<ref name="LAWeekly">[http://www.alternet.org/story/12254 "The Last Revolutionary: Sara Jane Olson Speaks"] by Greg Goldin, ''LA Weekly'', January 18, 2002</ref>
When Atwood and other core members of the SLA were killed in 1974 during a standoff with police near [[Watts, Los Angeles]], following their murder of the Oakland school superintendent,<ref name="MPR1">{{cite news |url=http://news.minnesota.publicradio.org/features/199908/03_zdechlikm_soliah/ |title=The Case Against Kathleen Soliah |publisher=Minnesota Public Radio |date=August 3, 1999 |accessdate=July 29, 2015}}</ref> the Soliahs organized memorial rallies,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/culture/features/tanias-world-the-inside-story-part-two-people-in-need-19751120|title=Tania's World: The Inside Story, Part Two: People in Need|work=Rolling Stone|access-date=2018-02-02}}</ref> including a rally in Berkeley's Willard Park (called [[Ho Chi Minh]] park by activists) where Soliah spoke in support of her friend Atwood, while being covertly filmed by the [[FBI]].<ref name="MSNBC timeline">[http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/23743392/ "Soliah-Olson timeline: Radical, bank robber, mom, inmate"]</ref><ref name="StarTribune">{{cite news |url=http://www.startribune.com/local/16894551.html |title=June 27, 1999: The life and times of Sara Jane Olson |work=Star Tribune |location=Minneapolis |accessdate=July 29, 2015}}</ref> At that rally, Soliah said that her fellow SLA members had been: {{quote|viciously attacked and murdered by 500 pigs in L.A. while the whole nation watched. Well, I believe that Gelina [Atwood] and her comrades fought until the last minutes, and though I would like to have her with me here right now, I know that she lived happy and she died happy. And in that sense, I'm so very proud of her. SLA soldiers – I know it is not necessary to say; but keep on fighting. I'm with you and we are with you!<ref name="StarTribune"/>}}
She asserted that Atwood "was a truly revolutionary woman ... among the first white women to fight so righteously for their beliefs and to die for what they believed in".<ref name="LAWeekly2">[http://www.alternet.org/story/12254?page=2 "The Last Revolutionary: Sara Jane Olson Speaks"], Greg Goldin, ''LA Weekly'', January 18, 2002</ref>
Now a fugitive, founding SLA member [[Emily Harris (SLA)|Emily Harris]] disguised herself and visited Soliah, who was on the job at a bookstore. Soliah later recalled, "I was glad she was alive. I expected them to be killed at any time." She felt sorry for the group and agreed to help the remaining group hide from the police and FBI.<ref name="LAWeekly2"/> She assisted them by procuring supplies for their San Francisco hideout and birth certificates of dead infants that could be used for identification purposes.<ref name="LAWeekly2"/>
===Crocker National Bank robbery and Myrna Opsahl murder=== On April 21, 1975, SLA members robbed the [[Crocker National Bank]] in [[Carmichael, California]], in the process killing 42-year-old [[Myrna Opsahl]], a mother of four depositing money for her church.<ref name="MPR3">[http://news.minnesota.publicradio.org/features/200201/17_stoltzef_olson/ "Sara Jane Olson charged with murder"], Frank Stoltze, [[Minnesota Public Radio]], January 17, 2002</ref><ref name="LAWeekly3">[http://www.alternet.org/story/12254?page=3 "The Last Revolutionary: Sara Jane Olson Speaks"], by Greg Goldin, ''LA Weekly'', January 18, 2002</ref> [[Patty Hearst]], who was switch [[crime scene getaway|getaway driver]] during the crime, provided the original information that led the police to implicate the SLA in the robbery and murder;<ref name="MPR3"/> she also stated that Soliah was one of the actual robbers.<ref name="MPR3"/> According to Hearst, Soliah also kicked a pregnant teller in the abdomen, leading to a [[miscarriage]].<ref>[http://www.postgazette.com/columnists/20010310roddy.asp "Payback from a long-forgotten account"], [[Dennis Roddy]], ''[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]'', March 10, 2001</ref>
Several rounds of 9 mm ammunition spilled on the floor and found in Opsahl's body<ref name="MPR4"/> during the robbery bore manufacturing marks that matched that of ammunition loaded in a 9 mm [[Browning Hi-Power]] [[semi-automatic pistol]] found by police in Soliah's bedroom dresser drawer at the SLA safehouse on Precita Avenue in San Francisco.<ref name="LAWeekly3"/> In 2002, new [[forensics]] technology allowed police to link these shells definitively to those found at Crocker Bank prior to charging the former members of SLA, including Soliah, with the crime.<ref name="MPR3"/> Prosecutor Michael Latin said that Soliah was tied to the crime through fingerprints, a palm print, and handwriting evidence.<ref name="LAWeekly3"/> The palm print was found on a garage door from a garage in which the SLA kept a getaway car.<ref name="foxnews">[http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,43343,00.html "Ex-Fugitive Sara Jane Olson Gets 20 Years to Life for 1975 Bomb Plot"] Fox News, January 18, 2002</ref>
===Los Angeles Police Department bombs=== On August 21, 1975, a bomb that came within 1/16 of an inch of detonating was discovered where a [[Los Angeles Police Department]] patrol car had been parked in front of an [[International House of Pancakes]] restaurant earlier in the day.<ref name="MPR1"/> After the bomb was discovered, all Los Angeles police were ordered to search under their cars, and another bomb was found in front of a police department about a mile away.<ref name="MPR1"/> Soliah was accused of planting the bombs in an attempt to avenge the SLA members who had died a year earlier in the standoff with LA police.<ref name="MPR1"/>
The [[pipe bomb]]s were rigged to detonate as the patrol cars drove away. One police officer present that day described the first bomb as one of "the most dangerous pipe bombs he had ever seen" and went on to say: {{quote|This device was designed to go off when that car was moved, and the only way you move a car is to get in and drive it. This bomb wasn't directed against property. It wasn't directed against the car. You could have thrown a device under the car and lit a fuse and then ran. It was directed at whoever got in the car and moved it, however it would have also taken out anybody in the vicinity.<ref name="MPR1"/>}}
At Soliah's 2002 sentencing hearing on the bombing, police officer John Hall,<ref name="foxnews"/> who had been in the car on top of the bomb described a little girl who stood feet away with her family: {{quote|Your honor, it horrifies me to think that the lives of dozens of innocent people, like that child in the window [would have ended] in an instant had the defendant and her co conspirators successfully carried out their terrorist acts.<ref name="MPR4">[http://news.minnesota.publicradio.org/features/200201/18_stoltzef_olsonsentence/ "Ex-fugitive Sara Jane Olson sentenced to 20 years to life"] ''Minnesota Public Radio'', January 18, 2002</ref>}}
Soliah was indicted in 1976 for setting the police bombs along with five other SLA members, but vanished before the trial could commence.<ref name="MPR1"/> When Soliah was eventually brought to trial years later, the evidence against her was not considered by prosecutors to be a "slam dunk", although enough to convince a jury of her guilt.<ref name="MPR1"/> Two witnesses who had originally testified in her grand jury indictment had died by the time she was found and brought to trial: a plumber who had sold materials used in the bomb had picked Soliah out of a lineup as one of the buyers, and a bomb expert had stated the explosive could have been built in Soliah's apartment. Police could not identify any [[fingerprint]]s on the devices other than those of the officers who had disarmed them;<ref name="MPR1"/> however, Soliah's fingerprint, handwriting and signature were identified on a letter sent to order a fuse that could only be used for bomb-making purposes, and components matching those used in the police car bombs were found in a locked closet at the Precita Avenue hideout that Soliah lived in with the other members of SLA.<ref name="LAWeekly3"/>
==Underground life, capture, and prosecution== [[File:1795Hillcrest.jpg|thumb|The house where Soliah lived under an assumed name in St. Paul, Minnesota]] In February 1976, a grand jury indicted Soliah in the bombing case. Soliah went underground and became a fugitive for 23 years.
She moved to [[Minnesota]], having assumed the alias Sara Jane Olson; the surname chosen being one of the most common names in Minnesota due to the large number of people of [[Scandinavian-Americans]] descent.<ref>{{cite news |title=Longtime fugitive is arrested after 23 years |date=June 17, 1999 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=861&dat=19990617&id=8ptHAAAAIBAJ&sjid=YX8MAAAAIBAJ&pg=1029,3098319 |newspaper=The Victoria Advocate |location=Victoria, Texas |page=8A |accessdate=July 29, 2015}}</ref> In 1980 she married the physician Gerald Frederick "Fred" Peterson, with whom she would have three daughters. Olson and Peterson went to [[Zimbabwe]] for a while, where Peterson worked for a British Medical missionary group. Then they settled in [[Saint Paul, Minnesota]], where Olson resumed her acting career.<ref>{{cite news |title=The life and times of Sara Jane Olson |author=Chuck Haga|date=March 21, 2008|url= http://www.startribune.com/june-27-1999-the-life-and-times-of-sara-jane-olson/16894551/|newspaper= Star Tribune}}</ref> She was active in Saint Paul on community issues.<ref name="MPR4"/> Her husband described the family as interested in [[Progressivism|progressive]] social causes.<ref name="MPR4"/>
On March 3, 1999, and again on May 15, 1999, Soliah was profiled on the ''[[America's Most Wanted]]'' television program. After a tip generated by the show, she was arrested on June 16, 1999. Soliah was then charged with conspiracy to commit murder, possession of explosives, explosion, and attempt to ignite an explosive with intent to murder.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.time.com/time/nation/article/0,8599,1885965,00.html | work=Time | title=Sara Jane Olson: American Housewife, American Terrorist | date=March 18, 2009 | accessdate=May 23, 2010 | first=Alex | last=Altman}}</ref>
Shortly after her arrest, Soliah legally changed her name to her alias, Sara Jane Olson. She also published a [[cookbook]] titled ''Serving Time: America's Most Wanted Recipes''.<ref>{{cite book |last=Olson |first=Sara Jane |date= 1999 |title= Serving Time: America's most wanted recipes |location= Minneapolis, Minnesota |publisher= Sara Olson Defense Fund Committee |isbn= 9780967847009}}</ref> On October 31, 2001, she accepted a [[plea bargain]] and pleaded guilty to two counts of possessing explosives with intent to murder.<ref name="MPR2">[http://news.minnesota.publicradio.org/features/2004/07/13_helmsm_sarajanesentence/ "Sara Jane Olson's 14-year prison sentence thrown out"] by Marisa Helms, Minnesota Public Radio, July 13, 2004</ref> As part of a plea bargain, the other charges were dropped.
===Plea controversy=== Immediately after entering the plea, however, Olson told reporters that she was innocent and that she had decided to take a plea bargain due to the climate after the [[September 11 attacks]], in which she felt an accused bomber could not receive a fair trial from a jury.<ref name="foxnews"/> "It became clear to me that the incident would have a remarkable effect on the outcome of this trial ... the effect was probably going to be negative," she said. "That's really what governed this decision, not the truth or honesty, but what was probably in my best interests and the interests of my family."<ref name="Angry">{{cite news| last = Declamecy| first = Dree| title = Angry judge orders hearing on Olson plea deal| publisher = [[CNN]] | date = November 1, 2001| url = http://archives.cnn.com/2001/LAW/11/01/olson.plea/index.html| accessdate = 2008-09-22}}</ref>
Angered by Olson's announcement that she had lied in court, Superior Court Judge Larry Fidler ordered another hearing on November 6, at which he asked her several times if she was indeed guilty of the charges. Olson replied "I want to make it clear, Your Honor, that I did not make that bomb. I did not possess that bomb. I did not plant that bomb. But under the concept of aiding and abetting, I plead guilty."<ref>[http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/c/a/2001/11/14/MN113298.DTL&type=printable "Now ex-fugitive Olson wants to stand trial"], Larry D. Hatfield, ''San Francisco Chronicle'', November 14, 2001</ref>
On November 13, Olson filed a motion requesting to withdraw her guilty plea and acknowledged that she did not misunderstand the judge when he read the charges against her. Rather, she said: {{quote|I realize I cannot plead guilty when I know I am not. ... Cowardice prevented me from doing what I knew I should: Throw caution aside and move forward to trial. ... I am not second-guessing my decision as much as I have found the courage to take what I know is the honest course. Please, Judge Fidler, grant my request to go to trial.<ref>{{cite news| title = Ex-fugitive seeks to withdraw plea in '70s SLA case| publisher = [[CNN]] | date = November 14, 2001| url = http://www.cnn.com/2001/LAW/11/14/olson.motion/index.html?related| accessdate = 2016-09-19}}</ref>}}
===Sentencing in explosives charges=== On December 3, 2001, Fidler offered to let Olson testify under oath about her role in the case. She refused. He then wondered "I took those pleas twice ... were you lying to me then or are you lying to me now?"—and denied her request to withdraw her plea. Observers expected her to serve only three to five years, but on January 18, 2002, she was sentenced to two consecutive 10-years-to-life terms.<ref name="MPR4"/> Fidler warned that according to California law, the Board of Prison Terms could later change the sentence to a lesser term.<ref name="MPR4"/> Olson's lawyers asserted that due to discrepancies between 1970s laws and current California laws, their client would most likely serve only five years, which could turn into two years for good behavior.<ref name="LAWeekly"/> The Board of Prison Terms did later change the sentence.
At her sentencing hearing, Olson's teenage daughter Leila, her pastor, and her husband spoke in her defense, while Olson's mother claimed on the stand that Olson had never been a part of the SLA and spoke against prosecutors and police she asserted had harassed the family.<ref name="MPR4"/>
===Sentencing in Opsahl murder=== On January 16, 2002, first-degree murder charges for the killing of [[Myrna Opsahl]] were filed against Olson and four other SLA members: [[Emily Harris]], Bill Harris, [[Michael Bortin]] (Olson's brother-in law who had married her sister Josephine), and [[James Kilgore]], who remained a fugitive.<ref name="MPR3"/> Judge Fidler arraigned Olson on the murder charges immediately following her sentencing hearing on January 18.<ref name="LAWeekly"/> Olson pleaded not guilty to that charge at the time.<ref name="LAWeekly"/> On November 7, along with the other three defendants, she pleaded guilty to a reduced charge of second degree murder.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2002-11-08/news/0211080283_1_bank-slaying-sara-jane-olson-bank-robbery|title=4 ex-SLA members plead guilty to '75 bank slaying|last=|first=|date=November 8, 2002|work=Chicago Tribune|access-date=|language=en}}</ref> She was sentenced on February 14, 2003, for the maximum term allowed under her [[plea bargain]], which was a six-year term<ref name="MPR2"/> [[Sentence (law)|concurrent]] to the 14-year sentence she was already serving.
==Incarceration and release== The state Board of Prison Terms had scrapped her original sentence in October 2002 in exchange for a longer 14-year sentence, saying Olson's crimes had the potential for great violence and targeted multiple victims. In July 2004, a judge said there was "no analysis" of how the state Board of Prison Terms had decided 14 years was appropriate, and threw it out. Her sentence was instead converted to five years, four months.<ref>[http://news.minnesota.publicradio.org/features/2004/07/13_helmsm_sarajanesentence/ "Sara Jane Olson's 14-year prison sentence thrown out"] Minnesota Public Radio News by Marisa Helms, July 13, 2004</ref> However, an appeals court panel restored her full 14-year sentence as of April 12, 2007. It ruled that a lower court did not follow procedure when they allowed Olson to appeal.<ref name="marieclaire.com"/><ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20070630115925/http://www.startribune.com/462/story/1120946.html "Sentence restored for Sara Jane Olson, former SLA member"] ''Star Tribune'' – April 14, 2007</ref>
Olson served her time at the [[Central California Women's Facility]] in [[Chowchilla, California|Chowchilla]]. Her custody status was "Close A",<ref name="A Life on Hold">[http://www.latimes.com/news/local/la-me-olson14aug14,0,4408160.story?page=2&coll=la-home-headlines "A Life on Hold in California Prison"] ''Los Angeles Times'', August 14, 2006</ref> which is reserved for inmates requiring the most supervision. This status limited her privileges and required that she be counted seven times a day. It also prevented her from being able to seek a relocation to a facility closer to her home. David Nickerson, Olson's attorney, stated that this status reflected the Department of Corrections' view that she was a potential flight risk.<ref name="A Life on Hold" />
Olson's husband and three daughters continued to support her during her imprisonment and took turns visiting her frequently in Chowchilla.<ref name="marieclaire.com">[http://www.marieclaire.com/world/news/Mom-Secret-8 "When Mom Has A Secret: An Exclusive Report on a Family Torn Apart"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070926234138/http://www.marieclaire.com/world/news/Mom-Secret-8 |date=September 26, 2007 }}, Tara McKelvey, ''Marie Claire'' June 2007. Accessed June 26, 2007</ref> In an interview with ''Marie Claire'' (coincidentally published by [[Hearst Corporation]]), Olson's 23-year-old daughter Emily Peterson dismissed her mother's radical past with the SLA, saying "She lived in Berkeley. It was kind of normal.<ref>[http://www.marieclaire.com/culture/news/a507/mom-secret/ "When Mom Has A Secret: An Exclusive Report on a Family Torn Apart"], Tara McKelvey, ''Marie Claire'' June 2007. Accessed January 23, 2018</ref> I always tell people she wasn't a terrorist. She was an urban guerrilla."<ref>[http://www.marieclaire.com/culture/news/a507/mom-secret/ "When Mom Has A Secret: An Exclusive Report on a Family Torn Apart"], Tara McKelvey, ''Marie Claire'' June 2007. Accessed January 23, 2018</ref> Olson herself has never expressed remorse or regret for her actions.<ref>(http://www.seattlepi.com/local/opinion/article/Sara-Jane-Olson-knows-no-remorse-1078618.php)</ref>
===Release from prison and rearrest=== Olson was released on parole from the Central California Women's Facility in Chowchilla on March 17, 2008.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.sfgate.com/news/article/Sara-Jane-Olson-released-from-prison-3290801.php | title=Sara Jane Olson released from prison | first=Steve | last=Rubenstein | date=March 22, 2008 | work=San Francisco Chronicle}}</ref> For five days, she stayed at her mother's home in Palmdale, and spent some time hiking with her husband.<ref name="sfgate.com">{{cite news| url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2008/03/24/BA26VP644.DTL&type=newsbayarea | title=SLA's Olson will fight return to state prison | first=John | last=Coté | date=March 24, 2008 | work=[[San Francisco Chronicle]]}}</ref>
On March 21, 2008, she was rearrested when it was decided that she had been mistakenly released a year early from prison due to a miscalculation by the parole board.<ref name="CNN">{{cite news | url = http://www.cnn.com/2008/CRIME/03/22/olson.custody/index.html | title ='70s radical-turned-housewife back in prison |publisher=[[CNN]] | date = March 22, 2008 | accessdate = 2008-03-22 }}</ref> Her attorney claimed that the action was a political move.<ref name="sfgate.com"/> Olson was taken back into custody by the California Department of Corrections and placed in the [[California Institution for Women]] in [[Corona, California|Corona]] for an additional year.<ref name="Return">{{cite news |first=Tim |last=Harlow |authorlink= |author2= |title=March 23: A return to prison, not St. Paul |url=http://www.startribune.com/local/16927196.html |work=[[Star Tribune]] |location=Minneapolis |date=March 23, 2008 |accessdate=March 15, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090321173018/http://www.startribune.com/local/16927196.html |archivedate=March 21, 2009 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
===Release and parole=== After serving a total of seven years, about half of her sentence, Olson was released from prison on March 17, 2009, to serve her parole in Minnesota. Police unions in both Minnesota and California protested the arrangement, stating that they believe her parole should be served in California, where her crimes were committed.<ref name="Associated">{{cite news |first=Don |last=Thompson |authorlink= |author2= |title=California due to release 1970s radical Olson |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5iCvqJ7PjTjtpMIEhEaYSuR4dm0SQD96UL2D01|publisher=Associated Press |date=March 15, 2009 |accessdate=March 15, 2009 }}</ref> In a letter to California Governor [[Arnold Schwarzenegger]], Minnesota Governor [[Tim Pawlenty]] also protested Olson being allowed to return to Minnesota.<ref name="Letter">{{cite news |title=Document: letter from MN Gov. Pawlenty to CA Gov. Schwarzenegger |url=http://stmedia.startribune.com/documents/3-16-09+Gov.+Pawlenty+letter+to+Gov.+Schwarzenegger.pdf?elr=KArksUUUoDEy3LGDiO7aiU |work=[[Star Tribune]] |location=Minneapolis |date=March 17, 2009 }}</ref>
===Daughter competes in ''American Idol''=== Olson's 28-year-old daughter, Sophia Shorai, was a contestant in [[American Idol (season 10)|the 2011 season]] of the talent show ''[[American Idol]]''.<ref name="Los Angeles Times">{{cite news |title='American Idol' contestant's link to LAPD attacks brings no protest from police union |url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/lanow/2011/02/american-idol-lapd.html |date=February 24, 2011 | work=Los Angeles Times}}</ref>
